results.title: Hush hush, sweet Charlotte
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Associates and Aldrich Company and Robert Aldrich
results.brief_description: Bette Davis plays Charlotte Hollis, a reclusive spinster still mourning the savage murder of the man she loved 37 years ago. When the state wants Charlotte’s grand property to construct a new highway, she turns to her cousin Miriam (Olivia de Havilland) and an old friend, Drew (Joseph Cotton) to help her resist. What follows is a series of chilling scares and shocks. Also stars Agnes Moorehead.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Associates and Aldrich Company and Robert Aldrich

results.title: Hurricane express
results.creator_credit: Mascot Pictures Corporation, Nat Levine, J.P. McGowan and Armand Schaefer
results.brief_description:
A saboteur known as “The Wrecker” is attempting to destroy the L&R railroad company in order to bolster an airline competing for the same route. When Larry Baker (John Wayne), a young air transport pilot finds out that his father, the railroad’s chief engineer, has been killed in one of a series of train wrecks, he is determined to track down the culprit. The villain’s talents as a master of disguise make his apprehension extremely difficult as a number of other characters come under suspicion. After a series of hair-raising attacks on the Hurricane Express, Baker eventually saves the day and the damsel (Shirley Grey) he loves.

Originally conceived and filmed as a twelve part serial, this version was truncated to a feature-length film for cinema release.

This film was co-directed by J.P. McGowan, an Australian-born actor/director and a founding father of the Hollywood motion picture industry.

results.title: Howard's End
results.creator_credit: Merchant Ivory Productions, Ismail Merchant and James Ivory
results.brief_description: From director James Ivory comes the magical and compelling film version of E.M. Forster’s classic novel; beautifully produced and brilliantly acted. The stoical and unyielding Mr. Wilcox (Anthony Hopkins) is part of the rich, ruling class which traditionally stomps on those who are weaker, his repression causes him to lash out at those who are not. The working class Mr. Leonard Baste is a dreamer, imaginative and intelligent, but he is trapped by his class and the ignorance of others. Two sisters, Margaret and Helen Schlegel (Emma Thompson and Helena Bonham-Carter) form a precarious bridge between these two men’s worlds and the result is a compelling and fascinating story about love and betrayal, privilege and poverty, a masterpiece of entertainment. Also stars Vanessa Redgrave, James Wilby and Samuel West.

results.title: How to steal a million
results.creator_credit: World Wide Productions, Fred Kohlmar and William Wyler
results.brief_description: How to steal a million is a romantic comedy caper film that re-teams star Audrey Hepburn and director William Wyler thirteen years after their classic film “Roman holiday” was made. “How to steal a million” is set among the high-end fine art world of museums, collectors, dealers and con-artists. Audrey Hepburn plays Nicole Bonnet, who’s father Charles (Hugh Griffith) specialises in art fraud, in particular ‘lost’ van Gogh masterpieces, which go on to command high prices at auction. Charles’ prized (fake) Cellini sculpture, Venus, is loaned for a public exhibition in Paris. Fearing that her father’s forgery will be discovered Nicole enlists the help of renowned art thief Simon Dermott (Peter O’Toole) to steal the sculpture. O’Toole plays the charming thief and Hepburn’s love interest with aplomb. The Paris setting and couture clothes (by Givenchy) for Hepburn make “How to steal a million” a delight to watch. Also stars Eli Wallach with a guest appearance by Charles Boyer.

results.title: How to make an American quilt
results.creator_credit: Amblin Entertainment, Sarah Pillsbury, Midge Sanford and Jocelyn Moorhouse
results.brief_description: Winona Ryder shines in this deeply moving and touchingly funny story of a Berkeley graduate student Finn (Ryder) who spends the summer at the home of her sparring Grandmother (Anne Bancroft) and great aunt (Ellyn Burstyn). Their house is a quiet haven where she intends to finish her latest thesis and think over a marriage proposal. This beautifully filmed tale brings unbridled passion, true love, betrayal, joy and heartbreak vividly to life in a captivating cinematic tapestry that celebrates finding your way and following your heart. Based on the novel by Whitney Otto.

results.title: How the West was won
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Cinerama, Bernard Smith, Alfred Newman, Henry Hathaway and John Ford
results.brief_description: This is the epic story of a family that moves West, and the many dangers encountered on the way. The story follows the Prescott family in their quest for land, gold, and glory - in their journey from the Erie Canal in the East to the magic of California in the West. Stars John Wayne, Debbie Reynolds, Carroll Baker and Lee J. Cobb.

results.title: How green was my valley
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Darryl F. Zanuck and John Ford
results.brief_description: Winner of five Academy Awards, this is an inspiring yet heart-breaking film from producer Darryl Zanuck and director John Ford. Sixty year old Huw Morgan looks back on his life as a boy (Roddy McDowall) in a small Welsh mining town. His reminiscences reveal the disintegration of the closely knit Morgans, and his devoted parents (Donald Crisp, Sara Allgood), while capturing the sentiments and issues of their time. Maureen O’Hara and Walter Pidgeon co-star in this acclaimed classic, the story of one family’s dreams, struggles and triumphs. Based on the famous novel by Richard Llewellyn. Includes performances by the Welsh Singers.

results.title: Housekeeping
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Robert F. Colesberry and Bill Forsyth
results.brief_description: Abandoned early in life, Ruth and Lucille have been raised by various relatives - now it’s Aunt Sylvie’s (Christine Lahti) turn. But Aunt Sylvie isn’t like their other relatives, she used to be a hobo and can’t seem to change her eccentric ways. She takes midday naps on park benches and wears an overcoat lined with old newspapers. Sylvie may be embarrassing, but she’s like a breath of fresh air to the two girls. Can Lucille and Ruth cope with Sylvie, and can Sylvie cope with the real responsibility of a family? This is a beautiful story of quirky relationships, loneliness, and the bonding of kindred spirits. Based on the book by Marilynne Robinson.

results.title: Houseboat
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Jack Rose and Melville Shavelson
results.brief_description: Poor little rich-girl ends up being the governess to a widower and his three children aboard an old houseboat. Sophia Loren and Cary Grant steam up the screen in this classic romantic comedy, complete with luscious colour and ‘VistaVision’ widescreen presentation from 1950s cinema. Resplendent in divine gowns designed by Edith Head, Sophia Loren learns about life and love with a few song and dance routines along the way. The three lead children are also delightful in this witty and entertaining film. Cast includes Martha Hyer and Harry Guardino. Winner of two Academy Awards for Best Song and Best Screenplay, written by Melville Shavelson and Jack Rose.

results.title: House on Haunted Hill
results.creator_credit: Allied Artists Pictures and William Castle
results.brief_description: Directed in 1958 by 50s B-grade horror maestro William Castle, “House on Haunted Hill” boasted the arrival of “Emergo”, a fluorescent skeleton that swept across the head of audience members in the cinema. Widowed playboy millionaire Frederick Loren (Vincent Price) invites 5 guests: a race driver, a columnist, the previous owner, a psychiatrist, and a typist to spend a night with Loren and his fourth wife, Annabelle, in the haunted house. At the strike of midnight the doors will close, the electricity will be out, and 12 hours lie ahead in a tenement in which there have been several mysterious deaths, including those of Loren’s previous 3 wives. The 4 men and 3 women have nothing in common, other than their need for money, and Loren has posted a reward of $10,000 for anyone who lasts the night. Low in budget, the film boasts several frightening scenes, including an acid bath and dismembered head, earning the film an M rating. Cast includes: Vincent Price, Richard Long, Alan Marshal, Carolyn Craig. Music composed and conducted by Castle collaborator Von Dexter. Remade in 1999 by William Malone.
